docs.lead_paragraph: In a major legal victory for tobacco companies, a Federal jury in Akron, Ohio, ruled yesterday that the companies did not have to repay dozens of union health and benefit plans in that state the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses. The lawsuit by the union health plans, which was patterned after recent tobacco cases brought by state attorneys general, was the first of its kind to reach trial. As a result, it was viewed by industry analysts as a watershed. A verdict in favor of the union plans, which were seeking up to $2 billion in damages, could have created financial turmoil for some cigarette makers.

headline.main: Verdict Backs Cigarette Makers In Suit by Union Health Funds

docs.abstract: Federal jury in Akron, Ohio, in a major legal victory for tobacco companies, rules that companies do not have to pay dozens of union health and benefit plans in that state the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats have long outnumbered Republicans here in the state's most populous village, where two-thirds of the 47,000 residents are black. But until Tuesday, a Democrat had not won a municipal race in 21 years. Now, however, Hempstead's Democrats have come back to life, handily unseating two incumbent Republican trustees in Tuesday's village elections after an aggressive get-out-the-vote effort.

headline.main: Hempstead Democrats Perk Up, Winning 2 Trustee Races

docs.abstract: Democrats Wayne J Hall and Hezekiah Brown unseat Republicans Jacqueline Jackson and Max Rodriguez in election for Hempstead, NY, village trustees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Budget Committee passed a Republican tax and spending blueprint tonight, sweeping aside objections from Democrats who said the plan promised too much in tax cuts and did too little to deal with the looming problems in Social Security and Medicare. The party-line vote of 22 to 18 came after another day of partisan clashes over how the nation should take advantage of its improving fiscal outlook. The Senate Budget Committee also moved toward approval of the Republican plan, with a vote expected on Thursday.

headline.main: House Panel Passes Blueprint For Tax Cuts and Spending

docs.lead_paragraph: A state appeals court temporarily blocked today a Whitman administration order that required insurance companies to reduce automobile policy rates by 13 percent to 15 percent for each of their customers. The order was issued by the State Department of Banking and Insurance last week after officials said a handful of companies failed to show how they would provide the saving for each of their customers.

headline.main: Ruling Blocks Trenton Order On Insurance

docs.abstract: New Jersey state appeals court temporarily blocks Gov Christine Todd Whitman administration order that required insurance companies to reduce automobile policy rates by 13 percent to 15 percent for each of their customers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHO should control patient care -- doctors at the patient's bedside or doctors working for the patient's insurance company? The Senate Labor Committee appears poised to answer ''neither'' when it votes this week on patient protections. The committee plans to turn the ultimate decision in cases where bedside physicians and insurance companies disagree over to expert panels, some at faraway academic medical centers. Exactly how to carry out external review remains controversial. But if the idea is handled creatively, it could sweep away the brawl over legal liability that doomed last year's efforts to pass a patients' ''bill of rights.''

headline.main: Economic Scene; Protecting a patient's rights without inviting lawsuits.

docs.abstract: Michael M Weinstein (Economic Scene) column on who should control patient care; says Senate Labor Committee will vote this week on patient protection bill that would turn ultimate decision in cases where beside physicians and insurance companies disagree over to expert panels, some at faraway academic medical centers; notes just how to carry out external review remains controversial; bill was proposed by James M Jeffords, Republican chairman of Labor Committee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ira C. Magaziner, the politically tone-deaf architect of President Clinton's ill-fated health plan, and Senator John B. Breaux, the deal-making chairman of a commission that failed to find a solution to Medicare's financial woes, share what might be called the hubris of health care reformers: the belief that they could devise an all-encompassing scheme to redesign a huge swath of America's health care system. Both failed spectacularly. Their efforts suggest that piecemeal, incremental changes are the only ones feasible at the moment, given the political and technical complexity of the subject.

headline.main: Politically and Technically Complex, Medicare Defies a Sweeping Redesign

docs.abstract: Robert Pear analysis contends that Ira C Magaziner, architect of Pres Clinton's ill-fated health plan, and Sen John B Breaux, chairman of commission that failed to find solution to Medicare's financial woes, believed that they could devise all-encompassing scheme to redesign huge swath of America's health care system; maintains that both failed spectacularly; says their efforts suggest that piecemeal, incremental changes are only ones feasible at moment, given political and technical complexity of subject (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory commission searching for ways to preserve Medicare disbanded tonight in disagreement, just three hours after President Clinton denounced its proposed report and said he would devise a plan of his own as an alternative. The commission ended its work without endorsing any recommendations to avert a financial crisis in the program, which provides health insurance for 39 million Americans who are elderly or disabled.

headline.main: MEDICARE PANEL, SHARPLY DIVIDED, SUBMITS NO PLAN

docs.abstract: Federal advisory commission on future of Medicare disbands in disagreement, hours after Pres Clinton denounces its efforts and threatens to devise plan of his own as alternative; ends work without endorsing any recommendations to avert financial crisis in program, which provides health insurance for 39 million elderly or disabled Americans; 17-member commission headed by Democratic Sen John B Breaux falls one vote short of 11 needed to approve its final report; 10 members voted for major changes that would convert Medicare into arena for competition among public and private health plans; Breaux and Republican Repr Bill Thomas vow to press fight for proposal, under which Govt would offer fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to purchase public or private health plan; Congress created commission in 1997, expecting it would pose difficult and perhaps politically unpopular choices needed to insure programs solvency; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the issues likely to draw serious attention from Congress this year, managed health care would seem to be particularly ripe for action. Republicans and Democrats agree that Americans need guarantees of better treatment from health plans and that most voters would applaud steps in that direction. But to say the two parties have that much in common is not to say they see eye to eye. As lawmakers begin anew this year to try to craft -- and, perchance, to pass -- a patients' bill or rights, many of the same obstacles that tripped them up in previous years again stand in their path.

headline.main: Curbs on Managed Care Still Divide Two Parties

docs.abstract: Republicans and Democrats in Congress agree that Americans need guarantees of better treatment from health plans but many obstacles that separated them in previous years again stand in path; parties remain split by philosophical differences over how extensively Federal Govt should regulate insurers, who are poised to unleash at least as many millions of dollars to block legislation as they have in past; are already engaged in intense political gamesmanship, with each side intent on snaring credit for any bill and suspicious of other's desire to actually enact law (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democrats who control the Assembly called today for a 4.6 percent rise in state spending, more than double the increase Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed, setting the boundaries for another fierce budget fight. Mr. Pataki assailed the Democrats' plan as irresponsible, raising the prospect that like last year, he might veto most of the money the Legislature adds to his proposed budget. Mr. Pataki has proposed a $72.66 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts April 1, while the Assembly Democrats describe their plan as $2 billion higher.

docs.lead_paragraph: An unsuccessful bid by life insurance companies to loosen regulations on their industry helped to push spending on lobbying in the Statehouse to another record last year, according to a report issued today. Over all, expenditures by lobbying clients increased by 7 percent last year over 1997, to $55 million, the report by the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying said.

headline.main: Spending by Insurers Pushes Albany Lobbying to Record

docs.abstract: Temporary New York State Commission on Lobbying reports that unsuccessful bid by life insurance companies to loosen regulations on their industry helped to push spending on lobbying in Statehouse to $55 million, increase of 7 percent from year earlier period (M)
